Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Identifying and modeling the advantages of regulating protein abundance in Caulobacter crescentus

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The cell cycle is a series of cellular events leading to DNA duplication and cell division, and ultimately to the production of two daughter cells. This project will address broadly relevant questions about cell cycle regulation. Namely, what is the function of the regulated degradation of crucial cell cycle proteins and how does this regulatory mechanism integrate with other levels of regulation to control the cell cycle? By addressing these questions, this work has the potential to have a significant impact on our basic understanding of how the cell cycle is regulated. This project will expose students to interdisciplinary research and allow undergraduate students in summer laboratory courses to be active participants in research.

The timed synthesis and degradation of specific proteins is a ubiquitous mechanism of cell regulation. However, some proteins can be regulated by covalent modification or binding to an allosteric effector. If a protein's activity can be controlled without the energetic cost of degradation and resynthesis, what circumstances would favor regulation by proteolysis? To address this question, the investigators are studying CtrA, a transcriptional regulator that promotes cell division in Caulobacter, yet also blocks chromosome replication. To reconcile these opposing functions, CtrA activity is temporarily eliminated from the cell just prior to chromosome replication by both dephosphorylation and proteolysis. Caulobacter strains expressing a non-degradable version of CtrA can still initiate chromosome replication, indicating that CtrA activity can be significantly reduced by dephosphorylation alone. However, cells with non-degradable CtrA have subtle defects that may compromise their competitive fitness. During each division cycle, ~9000 CtrA molecules are degraded and resynthesized. To understand the selective advantages conferred by this apparently wasteful strategy, experimental and modeling approaches will be used to predict and test the consequences of regulating CtrA only by phosphorylation. In particular, this study will investigate whether the periodic degradation and resynthesis of a neutral passenger protein confers a competitive disadvantage in Caulobacter, as in other bacteria. Caulobacter strains expressing steady levels of a non-degradable CtrA protein will be used to identify phenotypes that differ from cells with oscillating CtrA levels. Competitive fitness assays and quantitative microscopy approaches will test explicitly the predictions of existing mathematical models, e.g., that cells with non-degradable CtrA experience a delay in chromosome replication and a longer cell division cycle. Existing deterministic and stochastic models of the Caulobacter cell cycle will be revised, taking into account recent published findings. Stochastic spatiotemporal modeling will benefit from single-cell data on times of division, chromosome replication, and protein localization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the freshwater bacterium, Caulobacter crescentus, the cycle of chromosome replication and partitioning is inextricably linked to an asymmetric division process that buds off a motile ?swarmer? cell from its parental, sessile ?stalked? cell. The processes of DNA replication, cell differentiation and division are managed by four master regulators. These proteins interact with each other and with the chromosome origin (Cori) to coordinate progression through the cell cycle. The activities of these proteins are tightly regulated by three mechanisms: gene expression, post-translational modifications, and proteolysis. Among these important regulatory proteins, a central player is the protein CtrA. Given the variety of regulatory mechanisms governing the activities of CtrA and corresponding species, one might expect consistent, tight control over CtrA levels. However, Caulobacter cells exhibit great variation of CtrA populations among different cells and even at different period of the same cell. It is of great interest to understand how the cells maintain its activities under such a fluctuating situation.

 

In recent decades, the development of experimental technologies has enabled biologists to collect experimental data, generate the protein regulation diagrams, and build mathematical models to represent the interactions of these proteins. In this project, through collaboration among biologists, mathematician and computer scientists, a detailed mathematical model is developed that represent how Caulobacter cells regulate their activities in normal situation and under starvation conditions. This mathematical model was able to reproduce many key observations reported by different wet labs.

 

One key discovery in this mathematical model shows that, instead of trying to maintain a stable population of the key regulator CtrA (in its phosphorylation form), Caulobacter cells controls the ratio between its un-phosphorylated and phosphorylated form: CtrAu/CtrAp. As long as this ratio is kept in a normal range, cells can maintain the dynamics of the DNA replication with a very accurate and robust manner, even though those important regulators are under great fluctuation.

 

Another discovery in this mathematical model also demonstrates how Caulobacter cells respond to environmental change, particularly when there is no sufficient nutrition, called the starvation response. In that case, Caulobacter cells regulate its activity through secondary messengers to delay the transition from a swarmer type to its stalked type. This is equivalent to the strategy to delay children?s age to turn adults (to allow them to have their own children) when there are no enough food for the society. Such a mechanism is well adopted by other bacterial cells. This mathematical model well represents this strategy and it can be applied to other cellular systems to study their response mechanism under starvation condition as well.

 

This project also provides training for four graduate students, including three female students and one undergraduate student. The materials developed in this project have been used in curriculum developed in Virginia Tech.
